title: Bi-Weekly Music Discussion Thread
selftext:
What is r/India listening to? Share and discuss songs, playlists, artists, or anything music-related here!

If you're a musician yourself, please share your work so we can all hear what up-and-coming musicians are doing these days.

Don't just mention stuff, link it! Links that are official and provided by the artists themselves are preferred.

**Music Thread is posted every two weeks on Tuesday mornings |** [**Old Threads**](https://reddit.com/r/india/search?q=Bi-Weekly+Music+Discussion+Thread&restrict_sr=on&sort=new&t=all)

https://preview.redd.it/06d0xwq1x8n61.png?width=1487&format=png&auto=webp&s=4195dbb767ebd70a3209ea46a4497062e788c176
comments:
I'm really getting into scandinavian/north-german folk metal. Stuff such as Heilung, Danheim, Wardruna, etc. It's dope and as good as Mongolian folk metal like Altan Urag and the Hu. 

[Svanrand by Heilung](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VGzOj5JTMnE)

And it makes me wonder why there aren't similar options for decent Indian folk metal.

My three recos for the thread:  

Natalia Lacunza â€“ Todo Va A Cambiar. Interesting combo of Spanish vocals & jungle.  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4kFp-j7oMeQ  

American Aquarium â€“ All I Needed. Upbeat country rock.  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SMny3pRbPdM&t=33s  

The Lumineers â€“ Just Like Heaven. Nice acoustic cover of a Cure song.  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CDaA0cLBOUY&t=662s (11:02 to 14:28)

Rock:  
[https://youtu.be/xqds0B\_meys](https://youtu.be/xqds0B_meys)  
more rock: 

[https://youtu.be/csUf0MAUIs4](https://youtu.be/csUf0MAUIs4)

way more rock:

[https://youtu.be/2utDtpyjtkA](https://youtu.be/2utDtpyjtkA)

Huh. Interesting music.

This is an opinion and likely the kind that is not constructive and adds no value. When rendering folk sounds in metal style, like the song you linked has clear pagan vibes, the intent is to approach the essence of a bygone era's sound, beliefs or just culture more broadly, redefine and reconstruct it to, to suit the modern ears and tastes, and the end result I feel sounds "pretentious", besides the fact that it "creates" less and initiates more but let's not get into the semantics of art.
Regardless, Good music, thanks.

Think you're familiar with Agalloch, but if not check them out, not exactly folk metal, and American (pagan and not southern folk, don't fret) but carry no pretence. 

By the way, OM and Ulver have used Sanskrit hymns, and of the two songs I know there's little background music, they sound pretty okay I think.
Hip Hop/Rap: Something I put out last week: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZDE9IoCuunY

I don't necessarily disagree with your opinion. I find that my tastes do tend to favor the pretentious over the artistically sublime. Provided it sounds good and drives interesting visuals in my mind. Sometimes good art is about the distraction instead of the thoughtful. But then, to each their own. 

Absolutely love Om. Some of their pure instrumentation pieces are incredibly evocative. I'll check out Ulver and Agalloch. Thanks for the recommendations.

Look up Rudra, there are Singaporean metal with Hindu elements. 

I love The Down Troddence a lot because of Karnatic style. Others I love for same reason are Motherjane and Anand Bhaskar Project.

I think post rock is pretentious and yet I listen it, because,  like you said, not all music need to be artistically sublime.


>I find that my tastes do tend to favor the pretentious

I came off wrong, pardon my bad grammar. Hindi medium. Trying.

You're experimenting and exploring, and that alone makes you a proper patrician of the art. I'll be looking out for your comment in the next week's thread. 

Also, I was listening to Skyrim soundtrack and track 1 reminded me of the song you linked. Many parallels, total artistic freedom. Check it out if you've not.
